chapter.title: Universal design is a proactive approach to accommodations
chapter.content:
Many individuals in the field of adult education suggest that we develop learning, testing, and work environments so that any person, with or without disabilities, could access accommodations. To assist facilities and companies making these accommodations, Universal Design offers a proactive approach. 

In this topic, you will learn:

  • what universal design is;
  • how universal design helps individuals with LD;
  • types of universal design accommodations; and
  • resources for universal design. 

The Universal Design concept offers accessible design features and minimizes the need for individually or retrofitted accommodations. This means that accommodations can be built into programs and facilities to make them more accessible. 

Universal design for learning is an approach to curriculum design that can help teachers customize curriculum to serve all learners, regardless of ability, disability, age, gender, or cultural and linguistic background. Universal design for learning is a set of principles for designing curriculum that provides all individuals with opportunities to learn. Explore this fact sheet for more information about universal design for learning.

chapter.title: Universal design makes alternative media more accessible to everyone
chapter.content:
Some examples of the universal design concept already common in our everyday lives include closed-captioning options on the television. This serves individuals who are hearing impaired, as well as many other users who enjoy or benefit from that option. Another example is municipalities creating curb-cuts for individuals in wheelchairs. These also benefit individuals with strollers or other wheeled carts, individuals who have difficulty with stairs, etc. These universal design changes were originally meant to accommodate those with disabilities, but resulted in a  much wider scope by assisting all people who have access to or use these services.

The goal of universal design is to provide the best environment for equal access to resources. With a universal design approach, alternative media would be more accessible to the entire population without calling specific attention to those with learning disabilities. Universal design is about ease of use for all individuals.

Some of the more widely heralded technologies include e-Text for books, magazines, and newspapers; as well as mobile phone devices as a means to scan text or download e-Text to laptops for work or school. e-Text is fast becoming the medium of choice for a large percentage of the general population-with or without print reading disabilities.

One of the reasons for the increasing popularity of e-Text among adolescents and adults with learning disabilities is its portability. Digital files can be quickly downloaded and used in a variety of environments including mobile phones and tablets. For adolescents or adults with LD, mobile technologies offer a quick and comprehensive tool for managing the day-to-day reading and writing tasks both at school and work.

chapter.title: Training is essential to successfully accessing new technologies
chapter.content:
Training individuals with LD on how to access and use the new and emerging technologies is key to making accommodations more commonplace. Instruction is needed to teach students when using an accommodation is essential to a positive outcome. For example, training in active listening, how to use assistive technologies, and extended time allowances to gain proficiency are important activities to teach those with LD how to best structure, manage, and organize time.

chapter.title: Universal design shows promise for those with LD
chapter.content:
Understanding that learning is fluid and dynamic is key to ensuring ongoing education, particularly for individuals with LD. For most of us, it begins with reading. Those with LD often become discouraged and do not even contemplate postsecondary educational opportunities. In the world of work, many of these individuals are underemployed or lose their jobs when reading becomes essential to their employment. The profound changes in the digital world show encouraging signs that more and more people with LD will benefit from tools that incorporate universal design and ensure ease of use for all users.

Further Resources to Explore

The Job Accomodation Network (JAN) provides free resources and guidance on workplace accommodations and disability employment issues. JAN is funded by the U.S. Department of Labor Office of Disability Employment Policy (ODEP).

chapter.title: Resources for universal design
chapter.content:
The goal of Universal Design is to provide the best environment for equal access to resources. There are several helpful organizations that have developed resources, tools, and initiatives to support universal design. These include:

  • The Center for Applied Special Technology, CAST, is a nonprofit research and development organization that works to expand learning opportunities for individuals through Universal Design for Learning.
  • The University of Washington's Faculty Room is a space for faculty and administrators at postsecondary institutions to learn about how to create classroom environments and academic activities that maximize the learning of all students, including those with disabilities.
  • In the corporate environment, businesses like Microsoft and Apple integrate universal design accessibility features into their applications. These options include a wide arrange of alternative access, including basic voice recognition, word prediction, and abbreviation software. 
  • Other universal design accommodations are available through bookshare.org and Google's book share project. Both of these resources partner with public libraries to digitize and categorize public domain materials as well as digitally scan library books for greater access. 
  • In addition, the Alternate Text Production Center serves the alternate media needs of community colleges in California. From existing print or electronic documents, the ATPC creates alternate media products for use by California Community College students with print-related disabilities.
